title: Modbury Walks

images.title: Derek Harper / Modbury
images.caption: Looking down Galpin Street towards the town centre. This was once the main road in from the east, continuing along the line of Broad Street (centre right) and Church Street, but it is now a minor lane.

images.title: Derek Harper / Modbury from the southwest
images.caption: Modbury from the southwest. Taken from the lane to Hunts Cross, looking across the valley of the Aylestron Brook, with St George's church in its prominent position.

images.title: Derek Harper / Hillside overlooking Modbury
images.caption: Hillside overlooking Modbury. Shadows on the hill north of Little Modbury farm. The centre of Modbury is half a mile to the left. Seen from a gateway on the lane to Hunts Cross.

images.title: Derek Harper / Green lane near Modbury
images.caption: Green lane near the village. High to the southwest, the bare trees are along the lane from Modbury to Hunts Cross.

images.title: Derek Harper / Cow and gate and view
images.caption: Cow and gate and view. South Hams countryside above her ear.

images.title: Derek Harper / Ayleston Brook valley
images.caption: Ayleston Brook valley. A view up the valley from a gateway on Bluegate Hill near the top of Cottlass Lane, with a bocage-like area of small enclosed fields on the north-facing slopes.

images.title: Derek Harper / Bluegate Hill
images.caption: Bluegate Hill. Tufted vetch and other summer blooms brighten the laneside by this junction of the road with Cottlass Lane, dropping down to the right into the Ayleston Brook.

images.title: Derek Harper / Maize field and view
images.caption: Maize field and view to the north of the village. The west side of a maize field, seen from the road between Mary Cross and Sheepham. The hedge on the far side of the Sheepham Brook valley leads up to Ridge Road. (This point is at the extreme top left of that photo). In the distance, Western Beacon and southern Dartmoor.

description: This large village in South Devon is a nice place to enjoy a stroll. There's an attractive high street with lots of independent shops, a Grade I listed 14th century church and some lovely countryside to explore. This circular walk from the village explores the footpaths and country lanes to the south of the settlement. You'll visit the Mill Leat, Little Modbury and the Ayleston Brook on the walk. On the way there's some lovely views of the surrounding countryside and rolling hills.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Just to the west you can pick up the Erme Plym Trail in the neighbouring village of Ermington. Head south west and you could visit the delightful Wembury Point. There's a marine reserve here with a variety of sea birds and some of the most significant rock pools in the country. The Yealmpton Walk visits the area from the nearby village which lies on the River Yealm. In the pretty settlement you could visit the 400 year old Mother Hubbard's cottage. The quaint old dwelling provided the inspiration for the famous nursery rhyme. For more walking ideas in the area see the Devon Walks page.

display_address: New Road, Stoliford Farm, Modbury, South Hams, Devon, England, PL21 0RT, United Kingdom
